description: Borrowed from Urdu گاڑی‎ (“wheeled cart, carriage; car, truck, bus”), from Sauraseni Prakrit 𑀕𑀟𑁆𑀟 (gaḍḍa), 𑀕𑀟𑁆𑀟𑀻 (gaḍḍī), from Ashokan Prakrit *𑀕𑀸𑀟𑁆𑀟- (*gāḍḍa-).

entries.meaning: A wheeled cart or carriage (usually horsedrawn), used especially in Myanmar.
examples: A ramshackle gharry, all dust and venetian blinds, pulled up short opposite the group, and the driver, throwing up his right foot over his knee, gave himself up to the critical examination of his toes.

entries.meaning: (South Africa, military, slang) A jeep or small truck for conveying troops.
